body:
<!--
**PLEASE READ THIS FIRST:**
- Do not use the bug and feature tracker for support requests. Use the `cython-users` mailing list instead.
- Did you search for similar issues already? Please do, it helps to save us precious time that we otherwise could not invest into development.
- Did you try the latest master branch or pre-release? It might already have what you want to report. Also see the [Changelog](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/CHANGES.rst) regarding recent changes.
-->

**Describe the bug**
After recent update to gcc I am getting missing symbols when trying to load the .so generated by cython. In particular I am getting `throw_bad_array_new_lengthv`. After downgrading to gcc 10.2.0 the error disappears. 

**To Reproduce**
- install gcc 11.1.0
- compile any cython code
- ??
- error

**Expected behavior**
No missing symbols, in particular `throw_bad_array_new_lengthv`

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Linux
 - Python version 3.9.4
 - Cython version 3.07a

comment_data.body:
Works for me:
https://github.com/cython/cython/runs/2783184152?check_suite_focus=true

Maybe there's something wrong with your local installation?

I am confused is this for 0.29 branch? I am running the 3.07a branch atm. 

`gcc (GCC) 11.1.0` 

My setup file contains these flags:

```
compiler = "g++"
optFlag = "-Ofast"
cppv = "20"
flags = (
    f"{optFlag} -march=native -std=c++{cppv} -flto "
    "-frename-registers -funroll-loops -fno-wrapv "
    "-fopenmp-simd -fopenmp -unused-variable -Wno-unused "
    "-D_GLIBCXX_USE_CXX11_ABI=0 "
)```

Running a unittest on the package generates

```
ImportError: [some_path] undefined symbol: _ZSt28__throw_bad_array_new_lengthv
```
It works with the master/3.0 branch. Haven't tried 0.29.x.

There is a similar issue happening on julia
https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/40703
Did you try it without the `-D_GLIBCXX_USE_CXX11_ABI` option?
Yes, I have also tried setting the compiler version with `os.environ` but no cigar so far.

temporary work-around found!
Setting in setup.py
```
os.environ["CC"] = "g++-10"
os.environ["CXX"] = "g++-10"
```
and the modules work as expected. I think it is probably a gcc issue judging from the variety of dist having the issue.
Not sure if CXX does anything as it didn't work with just that flag.

No idea why it works in our CI setup then. Here's the output of the C++ tests run:

https://github.com/cython/cython/runs/2783184194?check_suite_focus=true

You can search the "Run CI" part of the logs for "buildenv" to see our system setup. And it definitely installs and uses gcc 11.1 further up.

Yeah could be that the ubuntu version is more stable(?) not sure why they would differ either. I updated last night and just now this issue appeared. 

I'll keep an eye out and come back when it hopefully disappears. Luckily,  for now this works. Let me know if you need anything from me.
Could this comment be the answer https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/issues/294#issuecomment-843634871 ?

Thanks @da-woods I saw this post too yesterday. I wasn't actually aware that conda packages compilers. The output of my extensions do not include any conda references however. I am looking into whether I can temporarily remove the compiler conda uses.
I believe this can be closed as it seems like a conda packed compiler issue - not a cython issue. For other peoples facing this issue look at the work-around above.
This is a real bug (as pystan's problem also demonstrates), but it is for conda.  Despite reading https://anaconda.org/contact/report I am still not sure where to file it.

Another workaround

Setting
`export CPPFLAGS="-D_GLIBCXX_USECXX11_ABI=0"` 
I get it to compile with gcc11 (it uses the old ABI).
@joshua-cogliati-inl proposed [a work around using the system's shared object instead](https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan/issues/294#issuecomment-870711100).
Wouldn't recommend making a symlink for this. Unless you really need the features of gcc11 I would just stick with 10 for now until conda updates its compiler.
Closing since it's not something that Cython can (or should) handle.

title: [BUG] Not compatible with gcc 11
